title: Omnicom Group Increases 2022 Organic Revenue Growth Forecast; John Wren, CEO of the advertising holding giant, lifted its forecast to 6.5%-7%, saying the firm continues to see strong demand for its services despite economic crosscurrents
text:
Marketers are still seeking its assistance, the company said, despite the economic uncertainty induced by factors such as the war in Ukraine, the effects of the pandemic, supply-chain snarls, higher inflation and rising interest rates.

"Even with this backdrop, we are continuing to see strong demand for our services, and based on our first-half results, are increasing our organic revenue growth forecast to between 6.5% to 7% for the full year 2022," Omnicom Chief Executive John Wren said on the company's earnings call Tuesday. That was up from its prior forecast of 6% to 6.5% in April, itself an upward revision of an earlier 5% to 6% estimate.

During the quarter, Omnicom focused on evolving its capabilities to meet the needs of its current and prospective marketer clients, most notably in the realm of e-commerce and retail media, Mr. Wren said.

Businesses including DoorDash Inc., Walmart Inc. and CVS Health Corp. have been increasingly offering advertisers ways to reach consumers using their retail shopping data, often by letting brands buy ads on the businesses' own websites or apps.

Mr. Wren cited Omnicom's e-commerce collaborations with companies such as Amazon.com Inc., Instacart Inc. and Kroger Co., and said the company employs more than 1,500 experts to help marketers navigate retail-media platforms.

Omnicom's organic revenue in the second quarter grew 8% over the quarter a year earlier for its advertising and media business; 21% for precision marketing, which helps clients reach consumers directly through digital platforms; and 16% for public relations.

Omnicom is the first among its advertising holding company peers to report second-quarter results. Publicis Groupe SA and Interpublic Group of Cos. Inc. plan to report on Thursday.

Amid recession fears and soaring prices, some analysts have clipped their forecasts for ad growth and tempered their outlooks on companies they consider particularly exposed, including advertising holding companies such as Omnicom.
